methods.javadoc: DO NOT USE THIS CONSTRUCTOR, USE create*(GenericFactory ...) FACTORY METHODS INSTEAD.
methods.name: <init>
methods.comment: DO NOT USE THIS CONSTRUCTOR, USE create*(GenericFactory ...) FACTORY METHODS INSTEAD.

methods.name: createSectionSymbol32
methods.comment: Creates a new section symbol.

params.name: sectionAddress
params.comment: the start address of the section

params.name: sectionHeaderIndex
params.comment: the index of the section in the section header table

params.name: name
params.comment: the string name of the section

params.name: symbolIndex
params.comment: index of symbol within corresponding symbol table

return.comment: the new section symbol

methods.name: createGlobalFunctionSymbol
methods.comment: Creates a new global function symbol.

params.name: name
params.comment: the byte index of the name

params.name: nameAsString
params.comment: the string name of the section

params.name: symbolIndex
params.comment: index of symbol within corresponding symbol table

return.comment: the new global function symbol

methods.javadoc:
Get the symbol table containing this symbol
@return symbol table
methods.name: getSymbolTable
methods.comment: Get the symbol table containing this symbol

return.comment: symbol table

methods.javadoc:
Get the index of this symbol within the corresponding symbol table.
@return index of this symbol within the corresponding symbol table
methods.name: getSymbolTableIndex
methods.comment: Get the index of this symbol within the corresponding symbol table.

return.comment: index of this symbol within the corresponding symbol table

methods.javadoc:
Returns true if this symbol's type is not specified.
@return true if this symbol's type is not specified
methods.name: isNoType
methods.comment: Returns true if this symbol's type is not specified.

return.comment: true if this symbol's type is not specified

methods.javadoc:
Returns true if this symbol is local.
 Local symbols are not visible outside the object file
 containing their definition. Local symbols of the same
 name may exist in multiple files without colliding.
@return true if this symbol is local
methods.name: isLocal
methods.comment:
Returns true if this symbol is local.
 Local symbols are not visible outside the object file
 containing their definition. Local symbols of the same
 name may exist in multiple files without colliding.

return.comment: true if this symbol is local

methods.javadoc:
Returns true if this symbol is global.
 Global symbols are visible to all object files 
 being combined. One object file's definition
 of a global symbol will satisfy another
 file's undefined reference to the same
 global symbol.
@return true if this symbol is global
methods.name: isGlobal
methods.comment:
Returns true if this symbol is global.
 Global symbols are visible to all object files 
 being combined. One object file's definition
 of a global symbol will satisfy another
 file's undefined reference to the same
 global symbol.

return.comment: true if this symbol is global

methods.javadoc:
Returns true if this symbol is weak.
 Weak symbols resemble global symbols,
 but their definitions have lower precedence.
@return true if this symbol is weak
methods.name: isWeak
methods.comment:
Returns true if this symbol is weak.
 Weak symbols resemble global symbols,
 but their definitions have lower precedence.

return.comment: true if this symbol is weak

methods.javadoc:
Returns true if this is an external symbol.
 A symbol is considered external if it's 
 binding is global and it's size is zero.
@return true if this is an external symbol
methods.name: isExternal
methods.comment:
Returns true if this is an external symbol.
 A symbol is considered external if it's 
 binding is global and it's size is zero.

return.comment: true if this is an external symbol

methods.javadoc:
Returns true if this symbol defines a section.
@return true if this symbol defines a section
methods.name: isSection
methods.comment: Returns true if this symbol defines a section.

return.comment: true if this symbol defines a section

methods.javadoc:
Returns true if this symbol defines a function.
@return true if this symbol defines a function
methods.name: isFunction
methods.comment: Returns true if this symbol defines a function.

return.comment: true if this symbol defines a function

methods.javadoc:
Returns true if this symbol defines an object.
@return true if this symbol defines an object
methods.name: isObject
methods.comment: Returns true if this symbol defines an object.

return.comment: true if this symbol defines an object

methods.javadoc:
Returns true if this symbol defines a file.
@return true if this symbol defines a file
methods.name: isFile
methods.comment: Returns true if this symbol defines a file.

return.comment: true if this symbol defines a file

methods.javadoc:
Returns true if this symbol defines a thread-local symbol.
@return true if this symbol defines a thread-local symbol
methods.name: isTLS
methods.comment: Returns true if this symbol defines a thread-local symbol.

return.comment: true if this symbol defines a thread-local symbol

methods.name: isAbsolute
methods.comment:
Returns true if the symbol has an absolute 
 value that will not change because of relocation.

return.comment: true if the symbol value will not change due to relocation

methods.javadoc:
The symbol labels a common block that has not yet been allocated. The symbol's value
 gives alignment constraints, similar to a section's sh_addralign member. That is, the
 link editor will allocate the storage for the symbol at an address that is a multiple of
 st_value. The symbol's size tells how many bytes are required.
@return true if this is a common symbol
methods.name: isCommon
methods.comment:
The symbol labels a common block that has not yet been allocated. The symbol's value
 gives alignment constraints, similar to a section's sh_addralign member. That is, the
 link editor will allocate the storage for the symbol at an address that is a multiple of
 st_value. The symbol's size tells how many bytes are required.

return.comment: true if this is a common symbol

methods.javadoc:
This member specifies the symbol's type and binding attributes.
@return the symbol's type and binding attributes
methods.name: getInfo
methods.comment: This member specifies the symbol's type and binding attributes.

return.comment: the symbol's type and binding attributes

methods.javadoc:
Returns the symbol's visibility. For example, default.
@return the symbol's visibility
methods.name: getVisibility
methods.comment: Returns the symbol's visibility. For example, default.

return.comment: the symbol's visibility

methods.javadoc:
Returns the symbol's binding. For example, global.
@return the symbol's binding
methods.name: getBind
methods.comment: Returns the symbol's binding. For example, global.

return.comment: the symbol's binding

methods.javadoc:
Returns the symbol's binding. For example, section.
@return the symbol's binding
methods.name: getType
methods.comment: Returns the symbol's binding. For example, section.

return.comment: the symbol's binding

methods.javadoc:
This member holds an index into the object file's symbol 
 string table, which holds the character representations 
 of the symbol names. If the value is non-zero, it represents a
 string table index that gives the symbol name.
 Otherwise, the symbol table entry has no name.
@return the index to the symbol's name
methods.name: getName
methods.comment:
This member holds an index into the object file's symbol 
 string table, which holds the character representations 
 of the symbol names. If the value is non-zero, it represents a
 string table index that gives the symbol name.
 Otherwise, the symbol table entry has no name.

return.comment: the index to the symbol's name

methods.javadoc:
Returns the actual string name for this symbol. The symbol only
 stores an byte index into the string table where
 the name string is located.
@return the actual string name for this symbol
methods.name: getNameAsString
methods.comment:
Returns the actual string name for this symbol. The symbol only
 stores an byte index into the string table where
 the name string is located.

return.comment: the actual string name for this symbol

methods.javadoc:
This member currently holds 0 and has no defined meaning.
@return no defined meaning
methods.name: getOther
methods.comment: This member currently holds 0 and has no defined meaning.

return.comment: no defined meaning

methods.name: getSectionHeaderIndex
methods.comment:
Every symbol table entry is "defined" in relation to some section;
 this member holds the relevant section header table index.

return.comment: the relevant section header table index

methods.javadoc:
Many symbols have associated sizes. For example, a data object's size is the number of
 bytes contained in the object. This member holds 0 if the symbol has no size or an
 unknown size.
@return the symbol's size
methods.name: getSize
methods.comment:
Many symbols have associated sizes. For example, a data object's size is the number of
 bytes contained in the object. This member holds 0 if the symbol has no size or an
 unknown size.

return.comment: the symbol's size

methods.javadoc:
This member gives the value of the associated symbol.
 Depending on the context, this may be an absolute value, 
 an address, etc.
@return the symbol's value
methods.name: getValue
methods.comment:
This member gives the value of the associated symbol.
 Depending on the context, this may be an absolute value, 
 an address, etc.

return.comment: the symbol's value

methods.javadoc: @see java.lang.Object#toString()
methods.name: toString

methods.javadoc: @see ghidra.app.util.bin.ByteArrayConverter#toBytes(ghidra.util.DataConverter)
methods.name: toBytes

methods.javadoc:
Sets the value of this symbol. The value is generally an address.
@param value the new value of the symbol
methods.name: setValue
methods.comment: Sets the value of this symbol. The value is generally an address.

params.name: value
params.comment: the new value of the symbol

name: ElfSymbol

fields.javadoc: Local symbols are not visible outside the object file containing their definition.
fields.name: STB_LOCAL
fields.comment: Local symbols are not visible outside the object file containing their definition.

fields.javadoc: Global symbols are visible to all object files being combined.
fields.name: STB_GLOBAL
fields.comment: Global symbols are visible to all object files being combined.

fields.javadoc: Weak symbols resemble global symbols, but their definitions have lower precedence.
fields.name: STB_WEAK
fields.comment: Weak symbols resemble global symbols, but their definitions have lower precedence.

fields.javadoc: The symbol's type is not specified.
fields.name: STT_NOTYPE
fields.comment: The symbol's type is not specified.

fields.javadoc: The symbol is associated with a data object, such as a variable, an array, etc.
fields.name: STT_OBJECT
fields.comment: The symbol is associated with a data object, such as a variable, an array, etc.

fields.javadoc: The symbol is associated with a function or other executable code.
fields.name: STT_FUNC
fields.comment: The symbol is associated with a function or other executable code.

fields.javadoc: The symbol is associated with a section. (Used for relocation and normally have STB_LOCAL binding.)
fields.name: STT_SECTION
fields.comment: The symbol is associated with a section. (Used for relocation and normally have STB_LOCAL binding.)

fields.javadoc: The symbol's name gives the name of the source file associated with the object file.
fields.name: STT_FILE
fields.comment: The symbol's name gives the name of the source file associated with the object file.

fields.javadoc:
In object files: st_value contains offset from the beginning of the section
 In DSOs:         st_value contains offset in the TLS initialization image (inside of .tdata)
fields.name: STT_TLS
fields.comment:
In object files: st_value contains offset from the beginning of the section
 In DSOs:         st_value contains offset in the TLS initialization image (inside of .tdata)

fields.javadoc: Symbol is in support of complex relocation.
fields.name: STT_RELC
fields.comment: Symbol is in support of complex relocation.

fields.javadoc: Symbol is in support of complex relocation (signed value).
fields.name: STT_SRELC
fields.comment: Symbol is in support of complex relocation (signed value).
